Lost credit card replaced with new card and new numbers. Credit score affected?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, replacing a lost credit card can have an impact on your credit score. When a credit card is replaced, the account is considered "experian," which means the account has been closed and a new account has been opened. This can affect your credit score in a few ways:

1. Length of credit history: The length of your credit history is an important factor in determining your credit score. When a card is replaced, the account age is reset, which can negatively impact the length of your credit history.
2. Credit utilization ratio: The credit utilization ratio is the amount of credit you're using compared to the amount of credit available to you. When a card is replaced, the new card may have a higher credit limit, which can increase your credit utilization ratio if you don't reduce your spending.
3. Account diversity: Having a mix of different types of credit accounts (e.g., credit cards, loans, mortgages) can help improve your credit score. When a card is replaced, the account type and age are changed, which can affect the diversity of your credit portfolio.
4. Inquiries: When you apply for a new credit card, the lender will perform a hard inquiry on your credit report, which can have a temporary negative impact on your credit score.

It's worth noting that the impact of replacing a lost card on
answers: The true answer is it depends because  it is up to the credit card issuer to follow the right path when issuing a replacement credit card. http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/will-replacement-card-hurt-my-score.aspx Typically, issuers will transfer the account history to the new trade line, says Barry Paperno, the consumer operations manager at FICO, the creator of the FICO scoring formula. The new account should have the old open date, so you should retain your payment history, he says. The credit limit and balance should also stay the same. http://blog.credit.com/2014/02/lost-or-stolen-credit-card-hurt-your-credit-scores-76724/ How Issuers Report Replacement Cards We asked the major card issuers how they report replacement cards to credit reporting agencies: American Express: The new card has the same open date and “Member Since” year as the previous card. The balance on the old account number is transferred to the new account number. All payment history transfers over. Bank of America: All transactions and account history are transferred to the new account number when there is a card replacement or renewal. Capital One: The new account number with all the original account data (original open date, etc.) is reported along with a notification to the bureaus that the new account number is replacing the old.  The two tradelines can then be ‘merged’ into one, so that all the applicable payment history, balance, etc. is now under the new account number. Chase: The original tradeline does not change. The history on the account remains, just the account number field is updated with the new account number. There is no “new” tradeline in this scenario.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Do dividend quotes for U.S. stocks include witheld taxes?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I'm glad to help! Dividend quotes for U.S. stocks typically do not include withheld taxes. When a company declares a dividend, the quoted price is the amount of money that the company is distributing to its shareholders, without any deductions for taxes.

It's important to note that dividend payments are subject to taxation, and shareholders are responsible for paying any taxes on the dividend income they receive. The amount of taxes owed will depend on the shareholder's individual tax situation and the tax laws in their state or country of residence.

To calculate the after-tax value of a dividend, you can use the following formula:

After-tax value = Dividend amount x (1 - Tax rate)

For example, if a company declares a dividend of $1 per share and the tax rate is 20%, the after-tax value of the dividend would be:

After-tax value = $1 x (1 - 0.20) = $0.80 per share

This means that for every $1 in dividend income, the shareholder would keep $0.80 after paying their taxes.

It's worth noting that some dividend payments may be eligible for a reduced tax rate
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

As a helpful assistant, I can provide you with information on how to block previously authorized ACH access.

Yes, it is possible to block previously authorized ACH access. The National Automated Clearing House Association (NACHA) rules allow banks to reverse or "Stop" an ACH transaction that has already been processed, but there are certain requirements that must be met.

To stop an ACH transaction, the originator of the transaction must provide written notification to the receiving bank, stating the reason for the stop request and including the ACH transaction ID number. The receiving bank then has the responsibility to stop the transaction and notify the originator of the stop request.

Additionally, if an ACH transaction is stopped after it has been processed, the originator may be charged a reversal fee by the receiving bank. The fee amount varies depending on the bank and the type of transaction.

It's important to note that stopping an ACH transaction is not a guaranteed solution to prevent unauthorized payments. Fraudsters may use stolen account information to initiate ACH transactions before the stop request is processed, which could result in the loss of funds.

To prevent unauthorized ACH transactions, it's essential to implement security measures such as:

1. Verifying the identity of the account holder before initiating an ACH transaction.
2. Implementing secure payment

answers: When you want to invest in an asset denominated by a foreign currency, your investment is going to have some currency risk to it. You need to worry not just about what happens to your own currency, but also the foreign currency. Lets say you want to invest $10000 in US Stocks as a Canadian. Today that will cost you $13252, since USDCAD just hit 1.3252. You now have two ways you can make money. One is if USDCAD goes up, two is if the stocks go up. The former may not be obvious, but remember, you are holding US denominated assets currently, with the intention of one day converting those assets back into CAD. Essentially, you are long USDCAD (long USD short CAD). Since you are short CAD, if CAD goes up it hurts you It may seem odd to think about this as a currency trade, but it opens up a possibility. If you want a foreign investment to be currency neutral, you just make the opposite currency trade, in addition to your original investment. So in this case, you would buy $10,000 in US stocks, and then short USDCAD (ie long CAD, short USD $10,000). This is kind of savvy and may not be something you would do. But its worth mentioning. And there are also some currency hedged ETFs out there that do this for you http://www.ishares.com/us/strategies/hedge-currency-impact However most are hedged relative to USD, and are meant to hedge the target countries currency, not your own.

Using stop-loss as risk management: Is it safe?[/INST]

As a helpful assistant, I'm glad to help you understand the concept of stop-loss orders in the context of risk management.

A stop-loss order is an investment strategy that involves setting a maximum loss level for a particular trade. When the price of an investment reaches that predetermined level, the stop-loss order automatically triggers a sell order, limiting potential losses to the defined amount.

Is stop-loss safe? The answer is both yes and no.

Yes, stop-loss can be a safe risk management tool in the following ways:

1. Protects against unexpected market movements: By setting a stop-loss order, you can limit your losses if the market moves against you. This can help you avoid significant losses due to unexpected price swings.
2. Helps manage risk exposure: By defining a stop-loss level, you can determine the maximum amount of risk you are willing to take on a particular trade. This can help you avoid over-exposure to the market or a particular asset.
3. Automates risk management: Once you set a stop-loss order, it will automatically trigger a sell order when the price reaches the defined level. This can save you the time and effort of constantly monitoring the market and making decisions under emotional pressure.

However, there are also potential downsides to consider:

1. False triggers: In fast-
answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Is a debt collector allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I'm glad to help! Yes, a debt collector is legally allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report.

The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) allows debt collectors to obtain your credit report for the purpose of collecting a debt. This means that when you owe money to a creditor or debt collector, they may request a copy of your credit report to verify the amount you owe or to determine whether you have the means to pay the debt.

It's important to note that debt collectors are only allowed to make hard inquiries on your credit report for the purpose of collecting a debt. This means they can't use your credit report for any other reason, such as to deny you credit or employment.

Additionally, the FCRA requires that debt collectors follow specific procedures when requesting a credit report. They must provide you with a written notice that includes the name of the creditor or debt collector requesting the report, the purpose of the request, and a statement indicating that you have the right to dispute the request.

It's worth noting that while a debt collector is allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report, this does not mean that the inquiry will automatically appear on your credit report. The credit reporting agencies have the dis
answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. This link seems to support that (and references the same part of the act, among others): According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, [...], any business can access your credit history without your permission provided the business has a valid "permissible purpose." The FCRA notes that one such permissible purpose is to review your credit information in connection with the collection of a debt. Thus, if you owe money to a debt collector, the debt collector has the legal right to pull and review your credit report. If they haven't been assigned the debt or own it outright, I believe you have a legal right to dispute it. Consult a lawyer if this is actually a situation you face.  Once use for this is if the debt collection agency has trouble locating you; since your credit report normally contains current and past addresses, this is one way to locate you.

What is the difference between a stop order and a stop limit order?[/INST]
pred:
Great question! Both stop orders and stop limit orders are popular order types used by traders to control their trading risks, but they have some key differences:

Stop Order:

A stop order is an order to buy or sell a security when the price reaches a certain level (called the stop price). When the stop price is triggered, the stop order becomes a market order, which means it will be executed at the current market price. The main advantage of stop orders is that they provide flexibility and allow traders to enter the market at a desired price without having to continuously monitor the price.

For example, if you think the price of XYZ stock is going to rise, you could place a buy stop order at $50. If the price reaches $50, your stop order will be executed at the current market price, which could be higher or lower than $50.

Stop Limit Order:

A stop limit order is similar to a stop order, but it has more specific execution requirements. With a stop limit order, you set both a stop price and a limit price. The stop price is the price at which the order will be triggered, and the limit price is the price at which the order will be executed.

For example, if you think the price of XYZ stock is going to rise but you only want to buy at a certain price, you could place a buy stop limit
answers: An attempt at a simple answer for the normal investor: A normal investor buys stock then later sells that stock. (This is known as "going long", as opposed to "going short").  For the normal investor, a stop order (of either kind) is only used when selling. A stop-loss sell order (or stop sell) is used to sell your stock when it has fallen too much in price, and you don't want to suffer more losses.  If the stock is at $50, you could enter a stop sell at $40, which means if the stock ever falls to $40 or lower, your stock will be sold at whatever price is available (e.g. $35). A stop-loss limit sell order (or stop limit sell) is the same, except you are also saying "but don't sell for less than my limit price".  So you can enter a stop limit sell at $40 with a limit of $39, meaning that if the stock falls to $40, you will then have a limit order in effect to sell the stock at $39 or higher.  Thus your stock will never be sold at $35 or any value below $39, but of course, if the stock falls fast from $40 to $35, your limit sell at $39 will not be done and you will be left still owning the stock (worth at that moment $35, say).

Yes, there is a converse to dollar-cost-averaging, which is called "lump-sum investing" or "one-time investment." Dollar-cost-averaging involves investing a fixed amount of money at regular intervals, regardless of the market's performance. Lump-sum investing, on the other hand, involves investing a single amount of money at one time, without any regular interval.

Lump-sum investing can be a low-risk strategy when done strategically. The idea behind it is that the market may be undervalued at a particular point in time, and by investing a large sum of money at that point, you can potentially benefit from the market's eventual increase in value. This strategy can be especially beneficial for investors who have a long-term investment horizon and are willing to take on some level of market risk.

There are a few key factors to consider when using a lump-sum investment strategy:

1. Time horizon: Lump-sum investing is best suited for investors with a long-term investment horizon, as it can take several years for the market to recover from any potential downturns.
2. Risk tolerance: Lump-sum investing involves taking on market risk, which can be higher than the risk associated with dollar-cost-averaging. Invest

Why would a central bank or country not want their currency to appreciate against other currencies?[/INST]
pred:
There are several reasons why a central bank or country may not want their currency to appreciate against other currencies:

1. Export competitiveness: If a currency appreciates, it makes a country's exports more expensive for foreign buyers, which can lead to a decline in demand and a negative impact on the country's trade balance. This can be particularly problematic for countries that rely heavily on exports for their economic growth.
2. Inflation: Appreciation of a currency can lead to higher import prices, which can contribute to inflation. This can negatively impact the purchasing power of consumers and lead to lower consumer spending, which can slow down economic growth.
3. Financial stability: Appreciation of a currency can lead to capital account reversals, where foreign investors sell their local assets and repatriate their funds. This can lead to a decline in the value of the domestic stock market and a decrease in investor confidence, which can negatively impact the overall financial stability of the country.
4. Exchange rate risks: Appreciation of a currency can expose a country to exchange rate risks, where the value of the currency can fluctuate significantly due to changes in market conditions. This can lead to significant losses for businesses that have assets or liabilities denominated in foreign currencies.
5. Interest rate competition: If a central bank wants to keep its currency from

Home equity is the value of the ownership interest in a property, calculated by subtracting the amount owed on the mortgage from the market value of the property. Home equity can grow over time as the value of the property increases, or as the mortgage balance decreases.

There are a few factors that can contribute to the growth of home equity, including:

1. Appreciation: If the value of the property increases over time, the home equity will also grow. This can happen when the local housing market appreciates, or when the property is renovated or improved in some way.
2. Mortgage paydown: As you pay down the mortgage balance, the amount of money owed on the property decreases, which can increase the home equity.
3. Interest rate changes: If interest rates fall, the cost of owning the property decreases, which can increase the home equity.
4. Tax benefits: Homeownership comes with tax benefits like mortgage interest and property tax deductions, which can help increase home equity.

It's important to note that home equity is not the same as investment returns. Home equity is the value of the ownership interest in the property, whereas investment returns are the profits generated from investing in other assets, such as stocks or real estate investment trusts (REITs). While

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

“Convertible -debt/note/bond/debentures” which of these are the same or different?[/INST]
pred:
Convertible debt, notes, bonds, and debentures are all financial instruments that are similar in some ways but also have some key differences.

Convertible debt is a type of debt instrument that can be converted into equity shares of the issuing company at a later date. This means that the holder of the convertible debt has the option to convert their debt into ownership in the company, usually under certain conditions. Convertible debt is often used by companies as a way to attract investors when they do not have access to the capital markets, or when they want to keep their costs low.

Notes, on the other hand, are a type of debt instrument that has a fixed interest rate and a maturity date. They are similar to bonds but are typically unsecured and have a shorter maturity date. Notes are often used by companies to borrow money for a short period of time, usually less than a year.

Bonds are a type of debt instrument that has a fixed interest rate and a maturity date. They are similar to notes but are typically secured by assets or collateral, which means that the issuer must use assets to repay the bond holders if they default. Bonds are often used by companies to borrow large amounts of money for a long period of time, usually greater than 10 years.

Debentures are a type
answers: They all basically mean the same thing - a type of debt than can be exchanged for (converted into) equity at some point. It's only the mechanics that can be different. A convertible bond is structured just like a regular bond - it (usually) pays periodic interest and has a face value that's due at maturity. The difference is that the bond holder has the option to exchange the debt for equity at some point during the life of the bond.  There can be restrictions on when that conversion is possible, and they typically define a quantity of equity (number of shares) that the bond can be converted into.  If the market price of the shares goes above a price that would make the shares more valuable than the bond, it's in the best interest of the bond holder to convert. A convertible note is typically used to describe a kind of startup financing that does not pay interest or have a face value that's redeemed, but instead is redeemed for equity as part of a later financing round.  Rather than specifying a specific number of shares, the bond holder receives equity at a certain discount to the rest of the market. So they both are debt instruments that can turn into equity investments, just through different mechanisms. A debenture is a fancy word for unsecured debt, and convertible debt could be used to described either structure above, so those terms could mean either type of structure.

answers: There are certain situations where you could legally pay yourself rent, but it'd be in the context of multiple business entities interacting, never in the context of an individual renting their own property.  Even if you could, any rent paid to yourself would count as rental income, so there'd be no benefit. Edit: I was hunting for examples where it might be acceptable, and didn't, but I found a good explanation as to why it is not acceptable from Brandon Hall on a BiggerPockets post: To get technical, you will be going up against the Economic Substance   Doctrine which states that a transaction has economic substance if:   (1) the transaction changes in a meaningful way (apart from Federal   income tax effects) the taxpayer’s economic position; and (2) the   taxpayer has a substantial purpose (apart from Federal income tax   effects) for entering into such transaction. By transferring your primary residence into a LLC, you would not be   changing your economic position. Further, you do not have a   substantial purpose for entering into such transaction other than to   simply avoid paying federal income taxes. So it might make sense if multiple people owned the LLC that owned the property you wanted to rent, and there are instances where company X owns holding company Y that owns an office building that company X rents space in. But if you're the sole player in the LLC's then it sounds like a no-go.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Interest on Amount Exceeding CC Balance?[/INST]
pred:
Interest on amount exceeding credit card balance is a common scenario that can occur when you carry a balance on your credit card. Here's a brief explanation of what happens:

When you use your credit card, you are borrowing money from the card issuer. The amount you owe, including any interest charges, is reflected on your credit card statement. If the amount you owe exceeds your credit limit, you may be charged interest on the excess amount. This is known as "interest on amount exceeding credit limit."

For example, let's say you have a $5,000 credit limit on your card, and you owe $6,000 on your card. In this case, you would be charged interest on the $1,000 excess amount. The interest rate on your card will determine how much you owe in interest each month.

It's important to note that not all credit cards charge interest on amount exceeding credit limit. Some cards may have a grace period during which you can pay off the excess amount without incurring interest charges. Others may charge a late fee or penalty APR if you exceed your credit limit.

To avoid interest on amount exceeding credit limit, it's essential to keep track of your spending and stay within your credit limit. You can also consider transferring your balance to a card with a 0% introductory A
answers: The best answer to this is: Read the fine print on your credit card agreement. What is common, at least in the US, is that you can make any charges you want during a time window.  When the date comes around that your statement balance is calculated, you will owe interest on any amount that is showing up as outstanding in your account.  Example...  To revise the example you gave, let's say Jan 1. your account balance was $0. Jan. 3rd you went out and spent $1,000.  Your account statement will be prepared every XX days... usually 30. So if your last statement was Dec. 27th, you can expect your next statement to be prepared ~Jan.24 or Jan. 27.  To be safe, (i.e. not accrue any interest charges) you will want to make sure that your balance shows $0 when your statement is next prepared.  So back to the example you gave--if your balance showed $1,000... and you paid it off, but then charged $2,000 to it... so that there was now a new set of $2,000 charges in your account, then the bank would begin charging you interest when your next statement was prepared.  Note that there are some cards that give you a certain number of days to pay off charges before accruing interest... it just goes back to my saying "the best answer is read the fine print on your card agreement."

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Why can low volume move a stock price drastically?[/INST]
pred:
Low volume can significantly impact a stock's price movement due to various factors. Here are some reasons why low volume can lead to drastic price movements:

1. High Liquidity Risk: Stocks with low volume often have a smaller pool of available buyers and sellers. This can lead to large price swings as a small influx of buying or selling can quickly deplete the available supply, causing rapid price movements.
2. Market Maker Influence: Market makers are crucial to the smooth functioning of financial markets. They provide liquidity by buying and selling shares at prevailing market prices. When volume is low, market makers may dominate the market, leading to exaggerated price movements due to their large orders.
3. Insider Trading: Low volume can provide an opportunity for insiders to execute large trades without attracting much attention. This can lead to significant price movements as insiders exploit the reduced liquidity.
4. Short Selling: Low volume can make it easier for short sellers to execute their trades without being detected. Short selling involves selling shares that the seller does not own, with the expectation of buying them back at a lower price to realize a profit. When volume is low, short sellers may be able to execute their trades without revealing their true intentions, leading to drastic price movements.

4. Growth prospects: The company's growth prospects, including its future earnings and revenue potential, can also influence the stock price. Companies with strong growth prospects are likely to
answers: There is certainly an obligation in some cases of a company to distribute profit, either as dividend or a stock buy back. Activist investors frequently push for one or the other when a company is doing well - sometimes to the detriment of future growth, in some eyes - and can even file shareholder lawsuits (saying the company is not doing its duty to its shareholders by simply holding onto cash).  Apple famously held out from doing either for years under Steve Jobs, and only in the last few years started doing both - a large dividend and a share buy-back which increases the value of remaining shares (as EPS then goes up with fewer shares out there).  Carl Icahn for example is one of those investors in Apple's case [and in many cases!] who put significant pressure, particularly when they were sitting on hundreds of billions of dollars. Ultimately, a (for-profit) corporation's board is tasked with maximizing its shareholder's wealth; as such, it can buy back shares, pay dividends, sell the company, liquidate the company, or expand the company, at its discretion, so long as it can justify to its shareholders that it is still attempting to maximize the value of their holdings.  Companies in their growth phase often don't return any money and simply reinvest - but the long-term hope is to either return money in the form of dividends on profits, or the sale of the company.

Why there's always a very huge volume of trades for AAPL every day before market close?[/INST]
pred:
The large volume of trades in Apple Inc. (AAPL) stock before the market close every day is largely attributed to the natural flow of institutional investor activities, particularly those of mutual funds and hedge funds. Here are some reasons why:

1. Earnings Season: Apple's fiscal year ends in September, which means the company typically reports quarterly earnings around the same time every year. To prepare for these earnings releases, mutual funds and hedge funds that track the technology sector or have a focus on AAPL stock, begin to buy or sell positions in the days leading up to the earnings release. This increased activity is a result of their clients rebalancing their portfolios in anticipation of the earnings report.
2. Window Dressing: Mutual funds and hedge funds also engage in "window dressing," which involves buying or selling stocks to make their portfolios appear more attractive to investors. This activity often occurs in the last few hours of trading before the market close, as investors review their portfolios and make adjustments to meet their target allocations.
3. Portfolio Rebalancing: Mutual funds and hedge funds also conduct portfolio rebalancing to ensure that their holdings align with their investment objectives. This process involves buying or selling stocks to maintain the desired allocation to the technology
answers: A huge amount of money in all financial markets is from institutional investors, such as mutual funds, government pension plans, sovereign wealth funds, etc.  For various reasons these funds do all of their trading at the end of the day.  They care primarily that their end-of-day balances are in line with their targets and are easy to audit and far less about "timing the market" for the best possible trades. So, if you're looking at a stock that is owned by many institutional investors -- such as a stock (like AAPL) that makes up a significant portion of an index that many funds track -- there will be a huge amount of activity at this time relative to stocks that are less popular among institutions. Even just in its introduction this paper (PDF) gives a fair overview of other reasons why there's a lot of trading at end-of-day in general. (In fact, because of all this closing activity and the reliance on end-of-day prices as signposts for financial calculations, the end-of-day has for decades been the single most fraud-ridden time of the trading day.  Electronic trading has done away with a lot of the straight-up thievery that floor traders and brokers used to get away with at the expense of the public, but it still exists.  See, for example, any explanation of the term banging the close, or the penalties against 6 banks just last month for manipulating the FX market at the close.)

prompt:

Can an ETF perform differently than its holdings?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, an exchange-traded fund (ETF) can perform differently than its holdings in several ways. Here are some reasons why:

1. Rebalancing: ETFs are required to rebalance their portfolios periodically to maintain their target weights. This means that the ETF may sell some of its holdings to buy more of others, even if their prices have changed. This can lead to the ETF outperforming or underperforming its holdings, depending on the market conditions.
2. Index methodology: ETFs are designed to track a particular index, but the index methodology may not always reflect the performance of the underlying holdings. For example, some indexes may use a weighting system that favors certain sectors or companies, which can lead to the ETF performing differently than its holdings.
3. Creation and redemption: ETFs are created and redeemed through the use of securities borrowing and lending, which can lead to differences between the ETF's performance and the performance of its holdings. This is because the creation and redemption process involves the use of securities lenders, who may charge fees or demand a premium for their services.
4. Trading costs: ETFs are traded on an exchange, and their prices may be influenced by trading costs such as bid-ask spreads and market
answers: The Creation/Redemption mechanism is how shares of an ETF are created or redeemed as needed and thus is where there can be differences in what the value of the holdings can be versus the trading price. If the ETF is thinly traded, then the difference could be big as more volume would be where the mechanism could kick in as generally there are blocks required so the mechanism usually created or redeemed in lots of 50,000 shares I believe. From the link where AP=Authorized Participant: With ETFs, APs do most of the buying and selling. When APs sense   demand for additional shares of an ETF—which manifests itself when the   ETF share price trades at a premium to its NAV—they go into the market   and create new shares. When the APs sense demand from investors   looking to redeem—which manifests itself when the ETF share price   trades at a discount—they process redemptions. So, suppose the NAV of the ETF is $20/share and the trading price is $30/share. The AP can buy the underlying securities for $20/share in a bulk order that equates to 50,000 shares of the ETF and exchange the underlying shares for new shares in the ETF. Then the AP can turn around and sell those new ETF shares for $30/share and pocket the gain. If you switch the prices around, the AP would then take the ETF shares and exchange them for the underlying securities in the same way and make a profit on the difference. SEC also notes this same process.

answers: Ditto mhoran_psprep.  I'm not quite sure what you're asking. Where does the money come from? When someone starts a bank, they normally get together a bunch of investors -- perhaps people they know personally, perhaps they sell stock -- to raise initial capital. But most of the money in the bank comes from depositors. Fundamentally, what a bank does is take money from depositors and loan it to borrowers. (Banks also borrow money from other banks and from the government.) They charge the borrowers interest on the loan, and they pay depositors interest on their deposits. The difference between those two interest rates is where the bank gets their profit. Where does the money go when you pay it back? Sure, I'd be happy to help!

UK Gilts are a type of government bond issued by the UK government to borrow money from investors. The interest rates and repayments on Gilts work as follows:

Interest Rates:
Gilt interest rates are determined by the market forces of supply and demand. The yield on a Gilt is the return an investor can expect to receive for investing in the bond, and it is calculated as a percentage of the bond's face value. The yield is made up of two components: the nominal interest rate, which is the rate at which the bond is issued, and the real interest rate, which reflects the rate of inflation.

For example, if the nominal interest rate on a Gilt is 2%, and inflation is 3%, the real interest rate is 1%. This means that for every £100 invested in the bond, the investor will receive £2 in interest over the course of a year, but the purchasing power of that £2 will be reduced by 3% due to inflation.

Repayment:
Gilts are repaid to investors when they mature, which can range from 5 to 40 years. The repayment amount is the face value of the bond, which is the amount borrowed by the government. For example, if an investor
answers: The name of the Gilt states the redemption date, but not the original issue date. A gilt with 8.75% yield and close to its redemption date may have been issued at a time when interest rates were indeed close to 8.75%. For example in the early 1990s, the UK inflation rate was about 8%. One reason for preferring high or low coupon gilts is the trade off between capital gains and income, and the different taxation rules for each. If you buy a gilt and hold it to its maturity date, you know in advance the exact price that it will be redeemed for (i.e. £100). You may prefer to take a high level of income now, knowing you will make a capital loss in future (which might offset some other predictable capital gain for tax purposes) or you may prefer not to take income that you don't need right now, and instead get a guaranteed capital gain in future (for example, when you plan to retire from work). Also, you can use the change in the market value of gilts as a gamble or a hedge against your expectation of interest rate changes in future, with the "government guaranteed" fallback position that if your predictions are wrong, you know exactly what return you will get if you hold the gilts to maturity. The same idea applies to other bond investments - but without the government guarantee, of course.

When does giving a gift “count” for tax year?[/INST]

Gift-giving during the holiday season is a common practice, but when does a gift "count" for tax purposes? In general, gifts are considered taxable income for the recipient if they are considered "gifts" under the Internal Revenue Code (IRC).

According to the IRC, a gift is any transfer to an individual without adequate consideration, such as money, goods, or services. The value of the gift is generally the fair market value of the item or service transferred.

For tax purposes, gifts are considered taxable income for the recipient if they meet certain thresholds. For cash gifts, the recipient must receive more than $15,000 in a calendar year without reporting the gift on their tax return. Any amount below $15,000 is not subject to tax reporting.

For non-cash gifts, such as clothing, household items, or other tangible personal property, the recipient must report the fair market value of the gift on their tax return if it exceeds $250. Gifts that are in excess of $5,000 to a single recipient (or $10,000 to a cumulative total of recipients) are considered "deemed gifts" and may be subject to gift tax.

It's worth noting that there are some
answers: Based on past case law, a check made payable to qualified charity and delivered (e.g., placed in the mail on 12/31 would count as delivered as it is out of the hands of the donor) would fall under the "constructive receipt doctrine". However, for non-charitable gifts (e.g., gifts to family members) it is the date the check is cashed (honored by the receiving bank).  This is important as the annual gift exclusion is just that "Annual".  Therefore, if I gift my child $14,000 by writing a check on 12/31/2014 but they deposit it on 1/3/2015 then I have used my annual gift exclusion for 2015 and not 2014. If I give $14,000 of cash to my child and then also give them Christmas gifts with a value of $1,000 I have exceeded my annual gift exclusion to that child.  Usually there are ways around this issue as I can give $14,000 to each and every person I want and if married my spouse can do the same.  This allows us to give $14,000 from each of us to each child plus $14,000 from each of us to their spouse if married and $14,000 from each of us to each of their children if they have any.

To quantify the differences in return between low expense ratio and high expense ratio mutual funds, you can use the following formula:

* Low Expense Ratio Fund: 0.20%
* High Expense Ratio Fund: 1.20%

Assuming the same average annual return of 8%, the difference in return between the two funds would be:

Difference in Return = (0.80% - 1.20%) = -0.40%

This means that the low expense ratio fund would outperform the high expense ratio fund by 0.40% per year.

The unprotected futures (if priced correctly) should account for dividend payments based on the dividend history and, since maturing after the payment, should earn you (you sell them) less money because you deliver the physical after the dividend has been paid. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are wash sale rules different for stocks and ETFs / Mutual Funds?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, wash sale rules are different for stocks, ETFs/mutual funds, and other securities. The wash sale rule is a tax provision in the US Tax Code that aims to prevent investors from claiming a loss on the sale of a security if they purchase a substantially identical security within 30 days before or after the sale.

For stocks, the wash sale rule applies when an investor sells a stock at a loss and then repurchases the same or substantially identical stock within 30 days. In this case, the loss is disallowed, and the investor is treated as having sold the new shares at the higher cost basis of the previously sold shares. This prevents investors from claiming a tax deduction for a loss on a stock sale if they Plan to buy the same stock back soon after.

ETFs/mutual funds, on the other hand, are not subject to the wash sale rule in the same way as individual stocks. Instead, the wash sale rule applies to the underlying securities in the fund, rather than the fund itself. This means that if an investor sells an ETF/mutual fund that holds a security at a loss and then buys substantially identical securities within 30 days, the loss may be disallowed.

It's worth noting that the wash sale rule does
answers: The IRS rules are actually the same.  26 U.S. Code § 1091 - Loss from wash sales of stock or securities In   the case of any loss claimed to have been sustained from any sale or   other disposition of shares of stock or securities where it appears   that, within a period beginning 30 days before the date of such sale   or disposition and ending 30 days after such date, the taxpayer has   acquired (by purchase or by an exchange on which the entire amount of   gain or loss was recognized by law), or has entered into a contract or   option so to acquire, substantially identical stock or securities,   then no deduction shall be allowed... What you should take away from the quote above is "substantially identical stock or securities." With stocks, one company may happen to have a high correlation, Exxon and Mobil come to mind, before their merger of course. With funds or ETFs, the story is different. The IRS has yet to issue rules regarding what level of overlap or correlation makes two funds or ETFs "substantially identical."  Last month, I wrote an article, Tax Loss Harvesting, which analyses the impact of taking losses each year. I study the 2000's which showed an average loss of 1% per year, a 9% loss for the decade. Tax loss harvesting made the decade slightly positive, i.e. an annual boost of approx 1%.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What's the catch with biweekly mortgage payments?[/INST]
pred:
Biweekly mortgage payments are a popular financial strategy that involves making half of the monthly payment every two weeks instead of one monthly payment. The idea behind biweekly payments is to make more frequent payments, which can lead to faster loan payoff and lower interest over the life of the loan. However, there are some potential catches to consider before switching to biweekly mortgage payments.

Firstly, biweekly payments may not always result in faster loan payoff as anticipated. This is because the extra payments are typically applied as principal, which can lead to a larger principal balance being paid off earlier, but not necessarily the interest part of the loan. To fully benefit from biweekly payments, it's essential to make sure that the extra payments are applied exclusively to the interest portion of the loan.

Another catch is that biweekly payments may not be suitable for all types of mortgages. For example, if you have an adjustable-rate mortgage with an initial period of lower interest rates, switching to biweekly payments may not result in significant savings during the introductory period. In some cases, it may even lead to higher payments during the adjustable period.

Additionally, some lenders may charge extra fees for processing biweekly payments, which can negate the benefits of this payment schedule.
answers: Depending on who you have the loan through and how they figure the interest charges (whether daily, monthly, bi-monthly, etc. normally monthly I would assume), your interest is probably figured either daily or once a month.   Let's assume that it is figured daily, otherwise it wouldn't make sense to make bi-weekly payments.   At 4% Annual Interest on a $150,000 home loan the interested added each day is about $16.44, but it doesn't stop there because it is compounding interest daily so the next day it becomes 4% of 150,0016.44 (which is negligibly larger amount) and they will tack on another $16.44. So what will happen is that the amount of interest you owe grows rather quickly, especially if you miss a monthly payment. The big thing with making your payments bi-weekly rather than a bigger payment once a month is that you pay off some of that principle right away and it won't collect interest for 14 more days. if the interest is only calculated once a month, make your full payment before the interest is calculated, the same goes for your credit cards.

Are capitalization rate and net profit margin the same thing?[/INST]

No, capitalization rate and net profit margin are not the same thing, although they are both important metrics used in real estate investment analysis.

Capitalization rate, or cap rate, is the rate of return on a real estate investment property based on the property's net operating income (NOI) and its purchase price. The cap rate is calculated by dividing the annual NOI by the property's purchase price and expressed as a percentage. For example, if a property has an NOI of $100,000 and was purchased for $1,000,000, the cap rate would be 10%. The cap rate is used to evaluate the potential return on investment for a real estate property and to compare different investment opportunities.

On the other hand, net profit margin is a financial metric that measures the amount of profit a business generates in relation to its revenue. It is calculated by dividing the business's net income by its revenue and expressing the result as a percentage. For example, if a business has net income of $100,000 and revenue of $500,000, the net profit margin would be 20%. The net profit margin provides insight into a business's overall profitability and can be used to evaluate the financial health of a company.

While both capitalization rate and net profit

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How much is one “lot” of EUR/USD?[/INST]
pred:
Great, I'm glad to help!

In the foreign exchange market, a "lot" typically refers to a standardized amount of currency that is used to determine the price of a currency pair. The size of a lot can vary depending on the currency pair and the brokerage firm, but some common sizes for EUR/USD lots are:

* Mini lot: 10,000 units of the base currency (EUR or USD)
* Micro lot: 1,000 units of the base currency
* Standard lot: 100,000 units of the base currency

So, for example, if you are trading EUR/USD with a standard lot size, you would need to trade 100,000 euros to execute one standard lot.

It's worth noting that the lot size you choose will affect your profit and loss potential, as well as your risk exposure. Trading larger lots typically requires more capital and carries greater risk, while trading smaller lots can provide more flexibility and lower risk, but may also result in lower profits.

It's important to carefully consider your trading objectives, risk tolerance, and capital availability when selecting a lot size for your trades.
answers: A lot (sometimes called a round lot) always refers to the quantity of physical good that you're getting, like a carton of eggs or a barrel of oil.  The tricky thing in the case of forex is that the physical good also happens to be a currency. A spot currency product trades in the denomination on the right-hand side (RHS) of the product name.  So if you're buying EUR/USD you are paying USD currency to get EUR "units", and if you're selling EUR/USD you are receiving USD by giving away EUR "units".  The EUR is the "physical good" in this case. The way I remember it is to think of all products (not just currencies) as trading pairs.  So AAPL in my mind is AAPL/USD.  When I buy AAPL/USD I am paying USD to get AAPL units.  When I sell AAPL/USD I am receiving USD by giving away AAPL units. The thing on the left is the physical good (even if it happens to be money) that you are exchanging, and the thing on the right is the money that you are exchanging. So, when I buy a lot of AAPL, I am buying 100 shares at their current price in dollars. Similarly, when I buy a lot of EUR/USD, I am buying 100K Euros at their current price in dollars.

On the other hand, in slower markets with fewer buyers, sellers may be less willing to offer discounts. In these cases, cash buyers may still be able to negotiate a slightly lower commission rate, but the savings may be less significant.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are RSUs ever taxed as long term capital gains?[/INST]
pred:
Restricted Stock Units (RSUs) are a form of equity compensation that companies use to reward their employees for their services. RSUs are taxed as ordinary income, but they can be taxed as long-term capital gains under certain circumstances.

Generally, RSUs are taxed as ordinary income when they vest and are received by the employee. This means that the employee will pay income tax on the fair market value of the RSUs at the time of vesting. However, if an RSU is held for more than one year before it is sold or transferred, it may be eligible for long-term capital gains treatment.

To qualify for long-term capital gains treatment, the RSU must be a "qualified opportunity stock" under the Internal Revenue Code (IRC). This means that the RSU must be a stock that is issued by a qualified opportunity zone business, and the RSU must be held for at least 10 years before it is sold or transferred.

If an RSU meets these requirements, any gain on the sale or transfer of the RSU will be taxed as long-term capital gain, which has a lower tax rate than ordinary income. This can provide significant tax savings for employees who receive RSUs and hold them for a long time.

It's worth noting that the tax treatment of RSUs can

answers: A subsidy is a payment made by a group (usually the state) to individuals or corporations in order to shift the balance if the rational economic decision for the individual would be detrimental to the group as a whole otherwise. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Is it a bet on price fluctuations and against the house?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I'm glad to help you understand the concept of betting in casinos. When you place a bet in a casino, it is not a bet on price fluctuations, but rather a bet against the house edge.

In a casino, the house edge is the built-in advantage that the casino has over the player. This advantage is built into the odds of each game, and it ensures that the casino will make a profit in the long run. The house edge is calculated as a percentage, and it can range from as low as 1% to as high as 30% depending on the game.

For example, in a game like roulette, the house edge is approximately 5.26%. This means that for every $100 you bet on roulette, the casino can expect to win $5.26 on average. The remaining $94.74 will go to the player as winnings, if they place a winning bet.

In other games like blackjack, the house edge can be much lower, but it still exists. For example, in a game of blackjack with a standard deck of 52 cards, the house edge is approximately 0.5%. This means that for every $100 you bet on blackjack, the casino can expect to win $0.50 on average.

It is also possible to have such a contract be settled in the underlying (if the cash value is appropriate, then the cash settlement can be used to purchase the underlying directly, if necessary).  Physical delivery was predominant until the last few decades.  Most traders, as opposed to hedgers or strategics, are going to prefer cash-settled contracts as opposed to physical delivery. It is possible to make trades with a brokerage firm such that the firm pays if the trader wins the bet. The cost charged to one contracting party should be set by the dealer in relation to prices being charged to parties making the opposite, matching bet (in this way, brokers are following market price, while traders are setting it). Disadvantages of buying a motorcycle with a lien:

answers: A lien is a mechanism to impede legal title transfer of a vehicle, real property, or sometimes, expensive business equipment.  That's why title companies exist - to make sure there are no liens against something before a buyer hands money to a seller. The lien can be attached to a loan, unpaid labor related to the item (a mechanic's lien) or unpaid taxes, and there are other scenarios where this could occur. The gist of all this is that the seller of the vehicle mentioned does not have clear title if there is a lien.  This introduces a risk for the buyer.  The buyer can pay the seller the money to cover the lien (in the case of a bank loan) but that doesn't mean the seller will actually pay off the loan (so the title is never clear!).  This article recommends visiting the bank with the seller, and getting title on-the-spot.  However, this isn't always an option, as a local bank branch isn't probably going to have the title document available, though the seller might be able to make some arrangement for a local branch to have the title available before a visit to pay off the loan. The low-risk approach is for the seller to have clear title before any money changes hands.

pred:
Short selling, also known as going short, is a financial strategy used by investors to profit from a decline in the price of a stock. In short selling, an investor borrows shares of a stock from a broker and sells them at the current market price. The investor then buys back the shares at a lower price, return them to the broker, and pocket the difference as profit.

To illustrate, let's say an investor believes that the price of XYZ stock is going to decline. They could short sell 100 shares of XYZ stock by borrowing those shares from a broker and selling them at the current market price of $50 per share. If the price of XYZ stock indeed declines to $40 per share, the investor can buy back the 100 shares at the lower price and return them to the broker. The investor would make a profit of $10 per share, or $1,000 on the 100 shares.

It's important to note that short selling is a high-risk strategy that can result in unlimited losses if the price of the stock rises instead of falls. This is because there is no upper limit to the price at which the stock can rise, and the investor is responsible for repaying the loan for the shares at the original
answers: The reason for selling a stock "short", is for when you believe the stock value will decrease in the near future. Here is an example: Today Exxon-Mobile stock is selling for $100 / share. You are expecting the price to decrease, so you want to short the stock, which means your broker (i.e. eTrade, etc) allows you to borrow shares without paying money, and those shares are transferred into your account, and then you sell them and receive money for the sale. But you didn't actually own those shares, you only borrowed them, so you need to return the shares to your broker sometime in the future.  Let's say you borrow 10 shares @ $100, and you sell them at the market price of $100, you receive $1,000 in your account. But you owe your broker 10 shares, which you need to return sometime in the future. A few days later, the share price has decreased to $80. Now you can buy 10 shares from the market at a total cost of $800. You get 10 shares, and return those shares to your broker. Since you originally took in $1,000, and you just paid out $800, you keep a resulting profit of $200

Is there a return-on-investment vs risk graph anywhere?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, there are several return-on-investment (ROI) vs risk graphs available that can help investors visualize the relationship between potential returns and risk exposure in various investment portfolios.

One of the most popular ROI vs risk graphs is the Sharpe Ratio, which was developed by William Sharpe in 1964. The Sharpe Ratio is a measure of excess return relative to the risk taken, and it is calculated as the average return minus the risk-free rate divided by the standard deviation of returns. The higher the Sharpe Ratio, the better the investment, as it indicates a higher excess return for a given level of risk.

Another commonly used ROI vs risk graph is the efficient frontier, which is a graphical representation of the set of investment portfolios that achieve the highest expected return for a given level of risk, or the lowest risk for a given level of expected return. The efficient frontier is a parabola that slopes downward as the risk level increases, indicating that higher expected returns require higher levels of risk taking.

There are also several other ROI vs risk graphs available, such as the Markowitz Mean-Variance Graph, the Black-Litterman Graph, and the Risk-Adjusted Performance Metrics Graph. Each of these graphs provides a different perspective on the relationship between ROI

In general, VAT is not charged on the cost of materials used in a trade or business, as they are seen as inputs or raw materials. However, if the tradesman is selling the materials to the customer as part of a taxable supply, such as when they are reselling them at a mark-up, then VAT will be charged on the sale of those materials.

For example, if a plumber buys a tool for £100 and uses it to fix a customer's boiler for £200, the £100 cost of the tool is an input VAT, and VAT is not charged on it. However, if the plumber decides to sell the tool to another customer for £150, then VAT is charged on the £50 profit made on the sale, as this is a taxable supply.

answers: Most people will never need to pay federal gift taxes. The federal gift taxes start after giving away 5.34 million over the course of your life. This number is adjusted annually for inflation. There are only two states that I know of which impose state gift taxes (Connecticut and Minnesota); in Connecticut, you need to start paying taxes if the lifetime value of your gifts exceed two million. Instead, you can claim an exemption. Since most people don't exceed that amount, its rare to ever pay taxes even when exceeding the annual exclusion amount. The annual exclusion amount is adjusted each year for inflation.

The Swiss stock market and the Swiss Franc (CHF) are generally inversely correlated, meaning that when the CHF strengthens, the Swiss stock market tends to weaken, and vice versa. This is because a strong CHF makes Swiss exports more expensive for foreign buyers, which can negatively impact the earnings and valuations of Swiss companies listed on the stock market.

However, it's worth noting that the correlation between the Swiss stock market and the CHF is not as strong as it once was. In the past, the CHF was widely used as a safe-haven currency, which meant that when investors were seeking shelter from geopolitical or economic turmoil, they would often buy the CHF. This often led to a positive correlation between the CHF and the Swiss stock market, as a stronger CHF would tend to boost the value of Swiss stocks.

Today, however, the CHF is no longer as widely used as a safe-haven currency, which has reduced its correlation with the Swiss stock market. This is partly due to the emergence of other safe-haven currencies, such as the US dollar and the Japanese yen, which have pushed the CHF into more of a commodity-type currency. As a result, the correlation between the CHF and the Swiss stock market has become more neutral, and is no longer as strongly influenced

The main export market for Switzerland is the UE. Some companies are doing most or all of their business on the Swiss market. Others are much more exposed to the the health of the global economy. When the Swiss franc appreciates, some companies suffer a lot from that and other less. It depends on their product portfolio, competitors, and other factors. The last decades have shown that how the Swiss Franc valuation is less and less correlated with the performance of the Swiss economy. The Swiss franc is used as a safe haven when the global economy goes bad or is uncertain. In those times, the Swiss franc can be overevaluated, at least as compared to the purchasing power. When the global economy is improving, the over-appreciation of the Swiss franc tends to disapear ; this is happening now (in Mid-2017). As a summary, the Swiss franc itself is not truly correlated with the competitiveness of the Swiss economy, but more about how people in the world are anxious. In this regard, it behaves a little bit like gold.

What is the opposite of Economic Bubble? [/INST]
pred:
The opposite of an economic bubble is a stable and sustainable economic environment characterized by steady growth, low inflation, and a balanced economy. An economic bubble occurs when there is a rapid increase in asset prices, such as stocks or real estate, driven by excessive speculation and a misallocation of resources. The bubble eventually bursts, leading to a sharp decline in prices and a period of economic contraction.

On the other hand, a stable and sustainable economy is characterized by steady growth, low inflation, and a balanced economy. This is achieved through a combination of sound monetary and fiscal policies, a strong and diverse economy, and a well-functioning financial system.

Some of the key features of a stable and sustainable economy include:

1. Slow and steady growth: The economy grows at a steady and sustainable pace, without experiencing sudden and unsustainable booms.
2. Low inflation: The general price level rises at a moderate pace, consistent with economic growth and supply and demand factors.
3. Balanced economy: The economy is balanced, with no single sector or group dominating the economy.
4. Sound monetary policy: The central bank manages the money supply and interest rates to promote economic growth, stability, and low inflation.
5. Strong and diverse economy:
answers: The opposite of an economic bubble is a bubble burst :p! Jokes aside though, an economic bubble occurs when the economy is in bull market mode and asset prices are growing very fast. It's usually measured by ratio's like price to earnings and the levels of various market indices. So, the opposite would be when valuations are falling very fast or are very low, and price to earnings ratios are low.  This condition is usually a recession. A recession is a market slowdown, generally after a bubble bursts, and severe recessions can become depressions if they last long enough (Great Depression, 1930s).  A bubble is not necessarily negative - stock prices usually rise a lot so paper wealth is greatly magnified. If you can get out in time, you're golden. Similarly, a recession isn't bad for everyone. Some investors keep large amounts of cash waiting for recessions so they can "buy low, sell high". For most people, however, recessions are negative because unemployment increases and some people get fired, and the economy slows down. Asset prices have fallen so their investments are worth less than they used to be (on paper), and people mainly have to bide it out until the market starts growing again.

The term "ex-dividend date" refers to the date on which the company's shares stop trading ex-dividend, which means without the entitlement to the upcoming dividend. answers: One occastion where "will not be quoted ex" is used is when a corporate action is occurring such as a spin-off. However, if the company is based abroad, it may not be worth the expense for them to have an additional securities listing on the local (US) exchange. prompt:

What is a negotiable security and how are they related to derivatives?[/INST]
pred:
A negotiable security is a financial instrument that can be transferred or sold to another party through a legal process called negotiation. This process involves the transfer of ownership and liability for the security, and is typically done through a written document, such as a negotiable instrument. Examples of negotiable securities include bonds, commercial paper, and certificates of deposit.

Derivatives, on the other hand, are financial contracts that derive their value from an underlying asset or group of assets. Examples of derivatives include options, futures, and swaps. These contracts allow investors to gain exposure to the underlying asset without actually owning it, and can be used to manage risk or speculate on price movements.

There are several ways in which negotiable securities are related to derivatives:

1. Securities can be used as collateral for derivative contracts. For example, a company may use its bonds as collateral to enter into a forward contract to buy or sell a commodity at a future date.
2. Derivatives can be settled through the transfer of negotiable securities. For example, if an option contract is exercised, the underlying stock can be transferred through a negotiation process, with the option holder receiving the stock and the option writer delivering the stock.
3. Negotiable securities can be used to create derivative instruments
answers: negotiability is a legal concept that permits free transfer of a security without the requirement of prior consent of the issuer.  that means the issuer must pay the current holder of the security, irrespective of who he is.  negotiability also protects a good faith buyer of the instrument from adverse ownership claims of purported prior holders of the instrument.  it is not related to "negotiating" the price or whatnot.  A negotiable security means the current owner does not have to be concerned about acquiring the asset via a bad chain of title b/c he can always assert that he is a "holder in due course" defense against such claims, and have absolute security in his ownership right over the asset.  securities and derivatives are different.  securities are transferrable instruments representing a direct claim on the issuer for the value of the security, whether debt or equity ownership.  derivatives are bilateral contracts, which can only be entered into with the consent of both parties, and can only be transferred by such consent.  derivatives represent a claim against the parties of to the derivative that depends on some economic reference which is outside of the financial condition of the two parties to the contract, such as interest rates, FX rates, commodity prices, etc.

How does a TFSA work? Where does the interest come from?[/INST]
pred:

A Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA) is a registered savings account that allows Canadian residents to save money tax-free. Contributions to a TFSA are not taxed, and withdrawals are also tax-free, as long as they are within the annual contribution limit and do not exceed the total accumulated balance of the account.

The interest earned on a TFSA comes from the investment income earned on the money saved in the account, such as from bank accounts, GICs, or mutual funds. The interest earned on a TFSA is also tax-free, which means that you won't have to pay taxes on the interest you earn.

Here's how a TFSA works:

1. Contribute money to your TFSA: You can contribute up to the annual contribution limit set by the Canadian government to your TFSA. The contribution limit is adjusted annually and is currently set at $6,000 per year.
2. Grow your savings: The money you contribute to your TFSA can grow tax-free over time, as you earn interest on the account.
3. Withdraw money tax-free: You can withdraw money from your TFSA at any time, and you won't have to pay taxes on the withdrawals as long
answers: As to where the interest comes from: The same place it comes from in other kinds of savings accounts. The bank takes the money you deposit and invests it elsewhere, traditionally by lending it out to others (hence the concept of a "savings and loan" bank). They make a profit as long as the interest they give for "borrowing" from you, plus the cost of administering the savings accounts and loans, is less than the interest they charge for lending to others. No, they don't have to pay you interest -- but if they didn't, you'd be likely to deposit your funds at another bank which did. Their ideal goal is to pay as little as possible without losing depositors, while charging as much as possible without losing borrowers. (yeah, I know, typo corrected) Why do they get higher interest rate than they pay you? Mostly because your deposits and interest are essentially guaranteed, whereas the folks they're lending to may be late paying or default on those loans. As with any kind of investment, higher return requires more work and/or higher risk, plus (ususally) larger reserves so you can afford to ride out any losses that do occur.

Are assets lost in a bankruptcy valued at the time of loss, or according to current value?[/INST]
pred:
Assets lost in bankruptcy are typically valued according to their current value at the time of the bankruptcy filing, not at the time of their initial purchase or loss. This is known as the "date of valuation" rule, which is a common practice in bankruptcy law.

The purpose of this rule is to ensure that the assets of the bankrupt estate are distributed to creditors based on their current value, rather than their initial purchase price. This helps to ensure that creditors receive a fair distribution of the assets, and that the bankruptcy process is conducted in an equitable manner.

There are some exceptions to the date of valuation rule, however. For example, if an asset has increased in value since the time of purchase, and the debtor had the opportunity to avoid bankruptcy but failed to do so, then the asset may be valued according to its initial purchase price. This is known as the "elective worth" rule.

It's worth noting that the date of valuation rule applies to both personal and business assets in bankruptcy. This means that any assets that were acquired before the bankruptcy filing, such as a home or investment property, will be valued according to their current market value, rather than their initial purchase price.

Overall, the date of valuation rule is an important consideration for individuals and businesses facing bankruptcy,

For example, some platforms have implemented restrictions on the timing of trades, such as limiting the ability to copy trades during a certain time window leading up to an important event. Other platforms may use algorithms to detect and prevent front running based on the volume and timing of trades.

answers: I don't think you can really classify it as front running. The statement "it is the bank's money, not yours" is a common misconception about credit card purchases. When you use a credit card, you are not borrowing money directly from the bank, but rather, you are borrowing a line of credit from the bank.

Here's how it works:

1. The bank extends a line of credit to you when you open a credit card account. This line of credit is backed by the bank's funds, but it is not a loan that you repay directly to the bank.
2. When you make a purchase using your credit card, you are drawing on that line of credit. The merchant receives the payment, but the bank is still responsible for covering the transaction.
3. You are not required to repay the full amount of the purchase immediately. Instead, you have a grace period, usually around 20-30 days, during which you can pay off the balance in full without incurring interest charges.
4. If you don't pay off the full balance within the grace period, interest charges will be applied to the outstanding balance. This means that the bank is actually lending you money, and you are paying interest on that amount.

So, while it is not technically the bank's money, but rather a line of credit extended to you, it is important to understand that you are still responsible for rep

Your exact rights will vary by bank, but mostly they need to follow the guidelines set by the Credit Card company - and you do need to be a bit careful - if you received goods which were fake or a dispute arises you may be up for shipping the goods back to the merchant - and you have a limited - but reasonable time - in which to make the dispute. If a put seller closes early, it can have a significant impact on the buyer. When a buyer purchases a put option, they are essentially buying the right to sell the underlying asset at a specified price (strike price) before a specified date (expiration date).

If the put seller closes early, it means they have sold the underlying asset before the expiration date, which can have the following consequences for the buyer:

2. Early Assignment: If the put seller closes early, the option may be exercised by the buyer, forcing the seller to sell the underlying asset at the strike price. This can result in the buyer losing money if the market price of the underlying asset is higher than the strike price.
3. Loss of Premium: If the put seller closes early, the buyer may also lose the premium they paid for the option. This can be a significant loss, especially if the option was purchased at a high premium.
4. Adjustment to the Option: If the put seller closes early, the option may be adjusted to reflect the new market conditions. This can result in the buyer receiving
answers: An option is freely tradable, and all options (of the same kind) are equal. If your position is 0 and you sell 1 option, your new position in that option is -1. If the counterparty to your trade buys or sells more options to close, open, or even reopen their position afterwards, that doesn't matter to your position at all. Of course there's also the issue with American and European Options. European Options expire at their due date, but American Options expire at their due date or at any time before their due date if the holder decides they expire. With American Options, if a holder of an American Option decides to exercise the option, someone who is short the same option will be assigned as the counterparty (this is usually random). Expiry is after market close, so if one of your short American Options expires early, you will need to reopen the position the next day. Keep in mind dividends for slightly increased complexity. American and European Options do not in any way refer to the continents they are traded on, or to the location of the companies. These terms simply describe the expiry rules.
